g.text: Mathematical Models: A Catalog of Essential Functions
(b) The graph is sketched in Figure 3. The slope is
sents the rate of change of temperature with respect to height.
±f there is no physical law or principle to help us formulate a model, we construct an
, which is based entirely on collected data. We seek a curve that “Its”
the data in the sense that it captures the basic trend of the data points.
Table 1 lists the average carbon dioxide level in the atmosphere, mea-
sured in parts per million at Mauna Loa Observatory from 1980 to 2012. Use the data
in Table 1 to Ind a model for the carbon dioxide level.
We use the data in Table 1 to make the scatter plot in Figure 4, where
Notice that the data points appear to lie close to a straight line, so it’s natural to
choose a linear model in this case. But there are many possible lines that approximate
these data points, so which one should we use? One possibility is the line that passes
through the Irst and last data points. The slope of this line is
